The initial definition of evidence - based practice was within the context of medicine , where it is well recognised that many treatments do not work as hoped [ 29 ] .Since then , many professions allied to health and social care have embraced the advantages of an evidence - based approach to practice and learning [ 5 - 8 , 30 ] .

One of the greatest achievements of evidence - based medicine has been the development of systematic reviews and meta - analyses , methods by which researchers identify multiple studies on a topic , separate the best ones and then critically analyze them to come up with a summary of the best available evidence .

Within this paradigm , usually , health experts create and publish clinical guidelines , which provide holistic guidance for the care for a certain disease .The creation of these clinical guidelines requires hard iterative processes in which each iteration supposes scientific progress in the knowledge of the disease .
